questions.question: The following pseudocode algorithm uses a count-controlled loop to read in 10 names and store them in the array Names[]. Rewrite the algorithm in pseudocode, using a condition-controlled loop instead of a count-controlled loop.
questions.answer:
One mark per bullet point
• Initialising a count variable outside of loop
• Correct use of loop with condition for 10 times (WHILE (DO)...ENDMHILE, REPEAT...UNTIL) with close
• Incrementing the count variable inside the loop
• Rest of algorithm correct

Examples
Count ← 1
REPEAT
OUTPUT "Please enter a name"
INPUT Name
Names[Count] ← Name
Count ← Count + 1
UNTIL Count > 10

Or
Count ← 1
WHILE Count <= 10 DO
OUTPUT "Please enter a name"
INPUT Name
Names[Count] ← Name
Count ← Count + 1
ENDMHILE

questions.answer: To check that a value has been entered.

questions.question: Write the validation check used in the algorithm.

Write an algorithm, using pseudocode, that validates the user's input as an integer. Include a condition-controlled loop that continues until the input is an integer. You do not need to declare variables.
questions.answer:
One mark per mark point, max five
Condition controlled loop used
Input of value into declared variable
Use of selection to test if input is an integer
Appropriate use of error message
Correct condition used to exit/terminate loop

For example
REPEAT
INPUT Number
IF MOD (Number, 1) <> 0
THEN
OUTPUT "Please try again"
ENDIF
UNTIL MOD (Number, 1) = 0

Alternative with use of DIV e.g. IF DIV(Number, 2) <> Number /2 is acceptable

questions.question: A range check is used to validate that the input temperature is an integer between –100 and 0, inclusive. Suggest suitable normal, abnormal, extreme and boundary test data to test if this validation check is working correctly.
questions.answer: One mark per correct piece of test data, Normal test data: -50 (any integer value between 0 and -100, inclusive) Abnormal test data: 50 (any value outside the range 0 and -100, inclusive, or any non-numeric input and non-integers Extreme test data: 0 // -100 Boundary test data: 1 // 0 // -100 // -101

questions.question: An input must be an integer between 10 and 95, inclusive. Suggest suitable abnormal and extreme test data for an integer between 10 and 95 inclusive, and give a reason for each of your choices.
questions.answer:
One mark per correct piece of test data, max two
One mark per correct reason, max two
Abnormal test data: 150 (any non-integer or any value outside the range 10 and 95)
Reason: This data is out of range so should be rejected
Extreme test data: 10 // 95
Reason: This is the smallest data entry that will be accepted // This is the largest data entry that will be accepted.
